In this work, a "hydrogen-free" strategy based on the ruthenium (Ru) modified REUSY molecular sieve catalysts was proposed, which can promote CO2 catalytic transfer hydrogenation using endogenous hydrogen induced by glycerol dehydrogenation. As the active component, Ru can not only act on the dehydrogenation reaction with glycerol, but also promote the hydrogenation reaction of CO2. Comparison experiments confirmed that under conditions of 200 °C, 36 h, and 7.92 g KHCO3, the reaction could obtain the highest yields over 10 wt.% Ru-deAl(5 h)-REUSY. The yields of formic acid and lactic acid were 19.81 % and 6.13 % respectively. In addition, when replacing the carbon source from KHCO3 to CO2 (dry ice), formic acid and lactic acid yields over 10 wt.% Ru-deAl(5 h)-REUSY catalysts were further improved, reaching 64.14 % and 17.13 %, respectively. This work demonstrated the feasibility of the "hydrogen-free" upgrade process realizing the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of CO2 into formic acid with glycerol as hydrogen donor. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ru-REUSY Transfer hydrogenation Glycerol Formic acid Lactic acid Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The excessive emissions of greenhouse gasses have led to an increasing greenhouse effect, and reducing carbon emissions to address climate warming has gradually become a global consensus [1–4]. As the main greenhouse gas, CO2 can be converted into high-value carbon containing compounds, which not only alleviates environmental problems but also effectively utilizes carbon resources, helping to achieve the carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals [5,6]. Among them, CO2 hydrogenation is a relatively simple way to produce formic acid (FA), with an atomic utilization rate of 100%, which conforms to the development trend of contemporary green chemistry. In addition, FA, as a basic chemical raw material, is widely used in industries such as rubber, pharmaceuticals, dyes, leather, etc. Therefore, in the context of "dual carbon", the development of the CO2 hydrogenation process directly to yield FA has great potential and good application prospects [7,8]. However, a large amount of industrial hydrogen needs to be provided, most of which comes from cracked petroleum gas in the traditional catalytic reactions of CO2 hydrogenation. If glycerol can be used as hydrogen donor, it can not only provide a hydrogen source for CO2 hydrogenation reaction but also solve the problem of glycerol excess, reducing the production cost of biodiesel and promoting the development of renewable energy [9,10]. Inspired by the work in this field, if the catalysts are found and developed achieving glycerol dehydrogenation reaction while ensuring the CO2 hydrogenation, it will be closer to industrial application. As one of the parallel reactions, the catalyst of CO2 hydrogenation to FA mainly consists of transition metal complexes and VIII group transition metals, among which Ru and Rh elements have relatively good catalytic effects according to current literature reports [11–14]. In 2004, Zhang et al. reported amine-functionalized silica immobilized ruthenium complexes for CO2 hydrogenation to FA using an in-situ synthesis method. The conversion frequency of FA was 1384 h−1, and the selectivity reached 100 % [15]. Ohnishi et al. theoretically investigated ruthenium-catalyzed hydrogenation of carbon dioxide to FA with DFT and MP4(SDQ) methods and proved the rate-determining step was the CO2 insertion into the Ru(II)-H bond [16]. Yaacoub et al. reported a promising heterogeneous approach toward FA dehydrogenation using a ruthenium PN3P pincer complex, [Ru–H(CO) (tBuPN3P)] (I), immobilized on a fibrous silica nanosphere, KCC-1, with a strong Lewis acid character [(Si–O–Si) (Si–O−)2Al–H] as well as good activity in FA dehydrogenation [17]. Mori et al. developed a stable and well-defined single-site Ru catalyst on the surface of a layered double hydroxide (LDH) in a basic medium which was proven to be efficient for selective hydrogenation of CO2 to FA under mild reaction conditions (2.0 MPa, 100 °C) [18]. As another parallel reaction, the most commonly used catalysts of the dehydrogenation of glycerol to lactic acid (LA) are noble metals (Ru, Rh, Pt, Pd, etc.) and non-noble metals (Co, Ni, Cu, Zr, etc.) [19,20]. The carriers are mostly carbon materials, metal oxides, and layered double hydroxides. Jiang et al. reported that Ru-Zn-Cul supported by hydroxyapatite ((Ru-Zn-Cul/HAP)) is an effective catalyst for the conversion of glycerol to LA of which the yields of LA can reach 70.9 % under the optimal conditions [21]. Pemmana et al. synthesized Ru-V bimetallic and monometallic catalysts loaded on activated carbon, containing 1.5 wt.% Ru and 0.5 wt.% V of which the LA yield was 75.5 % and the glycerol conversion rate was 98.7 % under mild operating conditions [22]. Finn et al. showed that thermally robust Ir(I), Ir(III), and Ru(II) N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) complexes with sulfonate-functionalized wingtips were highly prolific for this process, requiring no cosolvents other than aqueous base by overcoming the solubility challenge associated with known homogeneous catalysts for this reaction [23]. At present, there are few reports on catalysts used in the co-reaction of glycerol dehydrogenation to LA and CO2 hydrogenation to FA. Shen et al. demonstrated that glycerol may be transformed to LA while creating H2 via alkaline catalysis. As a result, a carbon source was added to react with H2, and LA and FA were successfully obtained using the one-pot approach [24]. Heltzel et al. reported a homogeneous catalyst composed of water-soluble ruthenium nitrogen heterocyclic carbon complexes, selectively providing LA and FA in the presence of an alkali between 150 and 225 °C [25]. However, in homogeneous reactions, metal components will remain in the products, making it so challenging to separate and purify that it is difficult for the catalysts to be recycled thus not suitable for industrial applications [26]. Therefore, the current research must stress the selection of appropriate metals and supports to develop and synthesize appropriate heterogeneous catalysts in an effort to improve the yields of catalytic transfer hydrogenation of CO2 to FA with glycerol as the hydrogen donor [27]. We herein prepared multiple sets of catalysts with different types by modifying REUSY molecular sieve and loading Ru element and found that the optimal catalytic activity was obtained under conditions of 200 °C and 36 h, with 5 h dealumination time and 10 wt.% Ru element loading amounts. The prepared catalysts were thoroughly characterized with respect to their crystal structure, porosity and acidity with XRD, XPS, Py-IR, CO2-TPD, and other characteristics. The XPS results demonstrated that Ru4+ helps the glycerol dehydrogenation reaction and CO2 reduction conducted efficiently. Py-IR and CO2-TPD characterization have confirmed that the types and quantity of surface acid-base sites on the Ru-deAl(5 h)-REUSY catalysts affect glycerol dehydrogenation and CO2 hydrogenation reactions. Dry ice can achieve maximum yields as the CO2 source under alkaline conditions compared to KHCO3, with FA and LA yields reaching 64.14 % and 17.13 %, respectively. Overall, the realization of catalytic transfer hydrogenation of CO2 to FA without external hydrogen supply demonstrated the feasibility of the “H2-free” upgrading process. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Glycerin (≥99 %), potassium bicarbonate, potassium hydroxide, ethanol (≥99.5 %), Ruthenium trichloride trihydrate and nitric acid were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). FA (≥98 %) and LA (1.0 M) were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. The β molecular sieve, LAY molecular sieve and REUSY molecular sieve were purchased from Nankai University Catalyst Factory Co., Ltd. The K10 molecular sieve was purchased from Wokai Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Other reagents were all analytical grade and used without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Catalysts were prepared through a two-step procedure, consisting of the dealumination of the carriers and then the introduction of Ru species via liquid impregnation method. In a typical process, place 5 g commercial carriers (Beta zeolite, Lay molecular sieve, REUSY molecular sieve, K10 molecular sieve) in a round-bottomed flask containing 100 mL concentrated nitric acid solution with a concentration of 65 %. Then place the flask in an oil bath and control the temperature to 80 °C at a stirring rate of 200 rpm for 20 h to obtain dealuminated carriers (deAl-Beta, deAl-Lay, deAl-REUSY, deAl-K10). The dealuminated carriers were filtered, washed thoroughly with deionized water, dried at 105 °C for 2 h and calcined at 550 °C for 6 h to remove inorganic impurities. Configured different concentrations of RuCl3 solutions ranging from 2 wt.% to 30 wt.%. Then took 1 g of commercial carriers/dealuminated carriers and suspended it in RuCl3 solution to prepare a mixture with different loading amounts. The mixture was sonicated for 30 min and then dried in an oven at 120 °C for 12 h. Finally, the ruthenium-supported catalysts (Ru-deAl-Beta, Ru-deAl-Lay, Ru-deAl-REUSY, Ru-deAl-K10) were obtained by roasting in a tubular furnace under air conditions of 550 °C for 6 h. The samples after calcination were directly used as the catalysts without any reduction treatment. Taking Ru-deAl-REUSY as an example, the catalysts obtained were labeled x wt.% Ru-deAl-REUSY, where x indicated the designated weight loading of metal in the samples. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were acquired on a D/max2550VB3+/PC diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα source (40 kV, 100 mA). Data points were acquired by step scanning with a rate of 2°·min−1 from 2θ=5°−50° The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were recorded at −196 °C using a Micromeritics ASAP-2020 surface area analyzer. The catalysts were degassed for 6 h at 150 °C before measurement. The specific surface area was calculated by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method and the middle hole diameter was calculated by Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. The micropore volume was determined by t-plot model, and the micropore size distribution was obtained by DFT method. FTIR spectra of the silanol vibration region and pyridine adsorption were obtained on a Perkin Elmer Frontier FT-IR. All pellets were pretreated in dry air at 450 °C for 2 h to remove any water in the material and pyridine steam was introduced into the sample chamber to adsorb pyridine for 0.5 h. Then the temperature of the sample chamber was controlled to 150 °C and 250 °C to desorb pyridine for 1 h respectively. The alkalinity and relative strength of the catalysts were analyzed by CO2 temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) using the Micromeritics AutochemII 2920 unit to determine the sample's adsorption capacity for CO2 under programmed heating conditions. The sample undergone drying to remove surface gas components, adsorbed saturated CO2 at room temperature, and then heated up at a 10 °C·min−1 program at an argon flux of 30 cm3·min−1. The CO2 desorption amount from 45 °C to 800 °C was recorded using a TCD detector and the desorption curve was plotted. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to characterize the electronic states and surface composition of metal on the catalyst surface and was performed on an Escalab 250Xi with Al Kα (1486.6 eV) as the photon source. The binding energy of elements was corrected by carbon (C ls=284.8 eV) and the data was processed and analyzed by XPS PEAK41 software. The Ru content in the catalyst was determined by ICP-OES (Perkin Elmer Optima 2100 DV). Before catalyst testing, it needed to use a mixture of HCl-HNO3 - HF to digest at 150 °C for 12 h, dilute quantitatively to a certain concentration, and pass the 0.22 μm filter membrane. 2.4 Catalytic reactions The preliminary test was conducted using 20 mL glycerol solution (0.33 M) and 7.92 g of KHCO3 as reaction substrates, and a catalyst was added to react at 200 °C for 12 h, as shown in the Eqs. (1). The control variables for the 5 groups of reactions were as follows: no catalyst; 0.1 g Beta zeolite; 0.1 g deAl(20 h)-Beta; 5.22 mg RuCl3·3H2O; 0.1 g 2 wt.% Ru-deAl(20 h)-Beta where 5.22 mg RuCl3 has the same molar number of Ru as 0.1 g 2 wt.% Ru-deAl(20 h)-Beta. The catalytic reactions of glycerol reducing CO2 were conducted in a 100 mL hydrothermal synthesis reactor that outer material was high-quality stainless steel, and the inner cup material was polytetrafluoroethylene, as shown in Fig. S1. 0.1 g catalysts were added with 20 mL glycerol solution (0.33 M) and 7.92 g of KHCO3 as reaction substrates and adjusted the reaction temperature and time according to the experimental requirements. (1) C 3 H 5 ( OH ) 3 + KHC O 3 → C H 3 CH ( OH ) COO · K + HCOOH + H 2 O 2.5 Products analysis Products analysis was analyzed by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC). The concentrations of all components were determined by comparison to the standard calibration curves. Table S1 shows the peak time and the linear equation related to concentration for each substance. Fig. S2 shows the HPLC chromatogram of the liquid sample after the reaction under optimal conditions. The glycerol conversion and FA yield and LA yield can be calculated as followed: (2) Glycerol conversion ( % ) = [ Glycerol ] inlet − [ Glycerol ] outlet [ Glycerol ] inlet × 100 % In the formula (2), Glycerol conversion is the conversion rate of glycerol, and [Glycerol]inlet and [Glycerol]inlet represent the amount of glycerol before and after the reaction respectively. (3) FA yield ( % ) = [ FA ] out [ CO 2 ] in × 100 % In the formula (3), FA yield is the yield of FA in the product, [FA]out represents the amount of FA in the product, and [CO2]in represents the amount of CO2 participating in the reaction. (4) LA yield ( % ) = [ LA ] out [ Glycerol ] in × 100 % In the formula (4), LA yield is the yield of LA in the product, [LA]out represents the amount of LA in the product, and [Glycerol]in represents the amount of glycerol involved in the reaction. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Selection of catalyst carrier Through the preliminary test (Fig. 1 ), it was found that the reaction of CO2 catalytic transfer hydrogenation could occur at 200 °C, but the yields of FA and LA were very low. When different catalysts were added, the yields of FA and LA increased, confirming that the presence of catalysts could reduce the activation energy of the reaction. As shown in Fig. 1a, when Beta zeolite, deAl-Beta, or RuCl3 solution were added, the yields of FA and LA slightly increased, but not significantly. However, when Ru was loaded onto deAl-Beta, the yields of FA and LA significantly increased. Then we attempted to replace the carrier and finally confirmed that the Ru-deAl-REUSY catalysts had a more significant promoting effect on the reaction of CO2 catalytic transfer hydrogenation (Fig. 1b). Therefore, further optimization experiments will be conducted over Ru-deAl-REUSY catalysts in the following experiments. 3.2 Optimization of the reaction conditions The effect of dealumination time on the catalytic activity of the 10 wt.% Ru-deAl-REUSY catalyst was evaluated by the results of CO2 catalytic hydrogenation reaction, as shown in Fig. 2 . It can be seen that when the REUSY carrier was not dealuminated, a small amount of LA and FA were generated during the reaction. After 3 h of dealumination pre-treatment on the carrier, the catalytic effect was greatly improved, yielding 4.30 % LA and 14.18 % FA; After 5 h of dealumination pre-treatment on the carrier, LA and FA were both reached the highest yields of 5.21 % and 14.64 %, respectively. Then the yields of LA and FA slightly decreased after 10 h of dealumination with the yields of LA decreasing to 3.86 % and FA decreasing to 13.22 %. As the dealumination time continued to increase, that was, theoretically, the aluminum in the REUSY molecular sieve had been completely removed by concentrated nitric acid. At this time, the yields of LA and FA rapidly decreased, which was worse than the catalytic effect without dealumination, with only 2.66 % FA yield. The yields of FA and LA exhibited a volcanic curve, which may be due to the influence of the degree of dealumination on the number of catalytic active sites on the surface of Ru-deAl-REUSY catalysts [28–30]. In summary, when the dealumination time of the REUSY carrier was 5 h, the catalytic reaction activity was optimal. As an active component of the catalysts, the loading amount of Ru also affected the catalytic performance. The effect of different Ru loading amounts on the catalytic activity of Ru-deAl(3/5/10 h)-REUSY catalyst was evaluated by the results of CO2 catalytic hydrogenation reaction, as shown in Fig. 3 (3 h, 5 h, and 10 h represented different dealumination time). With the increase of Ru loading, the yields of LA and FA always showed an increasing trend. Based on the analysis of 5 h dealumination time, when the Ru loading increased from 0 wt.% to 5 wt.%, the yields of FA rapidly increased from the initial 2.30 % to 13.07 %, and the yields of LA also rapidly increased from 1.09 % to 3.74 %. When the loading amount of Ru increased from 5 wt.% to 10 wt.%, the yields of both increased rapidly but were slightly lower than that of the first stage. When the loading amount of Ru was 10 wt.%, the yields of FA and LA reached 14.64 % and 5.21 % respectively and ultimately reached 19.13 % and 6.63 % when the loading amount of Ru continued to increase from 10 wt.% to 30 wt.%. This may be because Ru, as the active component of the catalysts, contributed to the process of glycerol dehydrogenation and CO2 hydrogenation reactions [31,32]. In conclusion, 10 wt.% Ru was selected as the optimal loading amount for the Ru-deAl(3/5/10 h) catalysts. The effect of reaction time on the catalytic performance of 10 wt.% Ru-deAl(3/5/10 h)-REUSY was evaluated by the results of CO2 catalytic hydrogenation reaction, as shown in Fig. 4 (3 h, 5 h, and 10 h represented different dealumination time). The yields of FA and LA increased at first and then decreased with the increase of reaction time. Still analyzed with 5 h of dealumination time, FA yields of 16.72 % and a LA yield of 5.18 % can be achieved after 24 h reaction. The highest yields of FA and LA were obtained with approximately 19.81 % and 6.13 % within 36 h of reaction. If the reaction time was further extended to 48 h, the yields of LA will slightly decrease, which may be due to the decomposition of LA [33–35,20]. Therefore, the optimal reaction time for this system was 36 h. The effect of temperature on the catalytic performance of 10 wt.% Ru-deAl(5 h)-REUSY was evaluated by the results of CO2 catalytic hydrogenation reaction, as shown in Fig. 5 . It can be seen that when the reaction time was fixed, the yields of FA and LA correspondingly increased with the temperature increasing. Because appropriate high temperature helped glycerol dehydrogenation, thereby promoting the reduction conversion of CO2 to FA. The yields of FA could reach as high as 14.64 % within 12 h and continued to rise to 16.72 % within 24 h. Within the following 12 h, the yields of FA slowly increased from 16.72 % to 19.81 %, at which point the yields reached their maximum. Continuing to increase the reaction time, the yields will decrease due to its instability. Similarly, when the temperature was fixed at 150 °C, the yields of FA and LA increased first, reaching the maximum within 36 h, and then decreased. The extension of temperature and time can promote the process of CO2 catalytic hydrogenation reaction to some extent [36,37]. Together, 200 °C was the optimal reaction temperature for this system. Overall, when the dealumination time of REUSY was 5 h, the highest yields of FA and LA were obtained reaching 19.81 % and 6.13 %, respectively with 10 wt.% Ru loading amount under conditions of 200 °C, 36 h over 10 wt.% Ru-deAl(5 h)-REUSY catalyst. 3.3 Analysis of the CO2 source and alkaline conditions As a reactant, the type of CO2 source also affects catalytic performance [38]. Dry ice has received more attention due to its low price and widespread use. Here, we took dry ice to investigate whether previous research can achieve good results in the catalytic reactions. In theory, KHCO3 can decompose to KOH and CO2. After calculation, 7.92 g of KHCO3 is equivalent to 3.48 g dry ice and 4.44 g KOH. Under the optimal conditions of the above experiments, 20 mL glycerol solution (0.33 M) was used as the reaction substrate, with different masses of CO2 (s) and KOH added, as well as 0.1 g 10 wt.% Ru-deAl(5/10 h)-REUSY catalysts. The reactions were carried out at 200 °C for 24 h. Table 1 showed the experimental results of catalytic reduction reactions of dry ice. It can be seen that there were almost no yields of LA and FA with yields of 3.02 % and 2.18 %, respectively in the reaction catalyzed by 10 wt.% Ru-deAl(5/10 h)-REUSY without adding alkali. Ru-deAl(5/10 h)-REUSY catalyzed the reduction of dry ice with glycerol could yield 17.13 % and 11.87 % LA, with FA yields as high as 64.14 % and 46.83 %, respectively after adding normal alkali. Compared with the two previous catalysts, the yields of FA and LA were significantly improved under the same conditions (Fig. 4). This indicated that 1 mmol KHCO3 is not equivalent to 1 mmol CO2 and 1 mmol KOH and the available alkalinity and the amount of CO2 that can participate in the reactions are relatively low in actual reactions. Since the high pressure caused by the large volume expansion during dry ice sublimation can promote the reaction, dry ice can achieve maximum yields as the CO2 source under alkaline conditions compared to KHCO3 [39,40]. 3.4 Catalyst characterization 3.4.1 BET characterization of catalysts In the preliminary test, this work confirmed that the type of catalyst carrier can affect catalytic performance. Therefore, we conducted nitrogen adsorption/desorption experiments on the carriers and summarized the pore structure characteristics obtained from nitrogen adsorption/desorption characterization in Table S2. It can be seen that in terms of specific surface area, total pore volume, and microporous pore volume, REUSY molecular sieve is the largest, followed by the Lay molecular sieve, Beta zeolite, and finally K10. Besides, the specific surface area, micropore volume, total pore volume, and pore size of REUSY and deAl(20 h)-REUSY did not show significant changes, indicating that HNO3 dealumination did not alter the pore structure characteristics of the molecular sieve. The adsorption/desorption experimental of nitrogen results were shown in Fig. 6 a. It can be seen that the REUSY molecular sieve is a typical microporous material. An adsorption hysteresis loop appears at 0.5<P/P0<0.8, indicating the presence of mesopores in the material [41]. Fig. 6b also shows the pore size distribution curves of REUSY, deAl(20 h)-REUSY, and Ru-deAl(0/10/20 h)-REUSY, further confirming that the Ru-deAl-REUSY catalyst is a microporous material with a small amount of mesopores, and the maximum pore size of the mesopores is about 4.84 nm. The increase of specific surface area and pore volume is beneficial to the adsorption of reactants and adds the active sites of the reaction [14,42,43]. Given this, we chose REUSY as the carrier, which is consistent with the preliminary test results. 3.4.2 XRD characterization and ICP test of catalysts Catalysts of 2 wt.%, 5 wt.%, 10 wt.%, and 20 wt.% Ru were selected from various loading amounts of Ru-deAl(5 h)-REUSY catalysts for X-ray diffraction and ICP test. The loading amount of Ru by ICP test were 1.8 wt.%, 4.7 wt.%, 9.8 wt.%, and 18 wt.%, respectively, indicating that the metal was successfully loaded onto the molecular sieve and the catalyst synthesis method controlled the loading amount stably and reliably. The XRD spectra are shown in Fig. 7 . RuO2 diffraction peaks were detected (JCPDS: 88–0322) at 28.0°, 35.0°, and 54.2° with Ru-deAl(5 h)-REUSY, corresponding to the (110), (101), and (211) crystal planes of RuO2, respectively [44]. As the loading amount increased, the diffraction intensity gradually increased and the crystallinity was good, confirming that the Ru element had been successfully loaded onto deAl-REUSY molecular sieve and distributed uniformly. The ICP test results also confirmed that the control of Ru loading by the catalyst synthesis method was reliable and stable. 3.4.3 XPS characterization of catalysts XPS analyses were performed on the catalyst 10 wt.% Ru-deAl(5 h)-REUSY, ranging from 0 to 1350 eV. As can be seen from Fig. 8 a, the Ru element was successfully loaded on the catalyst. To further explore the valence state of Ru, the XPS analyses were further carried out. High resolution Ru 3d XPS scan in Fig. 8b exhibits two prominent signals at 285.0 and 281.2 eV, assigned to 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 of Ru4+, respectively [45–47]. At the same time, we also investigated the Ru 3d XPS spectra of catalysts with different Ru loading as shown in Fig. S3. With the increase of Ru loading, the binding energy position shifted to a higher place. According to Zhao et al. report, Ru4+ mainly contributed to the process of CO2 hydrogenation reaction [48]. However, the XPS spectra in Fig. S3 showed that the valence state of Ru element of the four catalysts with different loading amounts in this paper were all Ru4+, indicating that the valence state of Ru element was not a key factor affecting catalytic activity in this system. 3.4.4 Acid−base characterization of catalysts To further identify the surface acidity, the pyridine adsorption IR spectroscopies were taken out. Three main classes of vibrations could be assigned: vibrations related to physiosorbed and/or hydrogen-bonded pyridine generated by both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites (1488 cm−1); vibrations arising from coordination of pyridine to Lewis acid centers (1446 cm−1); and vibrations related to pyridine protonated by Brønsted acid centers (1540 cm−1) [49,50]. The quantitative analysis of different types of acid sites was listed in Table 2 . It can be seen that the Brønsted acid and Lewis acid contents in parent REUSY are 0.0.496 mmol·g−1 and 0.164 mmol·g−1, respectively. The Si/Al ratio of molecular sieves largely determines their thermal stability, hydrothermal stability, number of acidic centers, adsorption and desorption properties, etc. Therefore, we adjusted the Si/Al ratio through HNO3 treatment to adjust acid type and content of the molecular sieve. After dealumination, Brønsted acid and Lewis acid sites of were largely removed with only 0.017 mmol·g−1 and 0.024 mmol·g−1, respectively. The illustration in Fig. 9 is an enlarged image of the deAl-REUSY, Ru-deAl(20 h)-REUSY, Ru-deAl(10 h)-REUSY, Ru-deAl(5 h)-REUSY. We can clearly see that when Ru was loaded onto the dealuminated molecular sieve, the Brønsted acid content increased and the Lewis acid content decreased. When the dealumination time of the catalysts increased, the content of Brønsted acid content decreased while Lewis acid content decreased at first and then maintained stability. Based on the above analysis and the experimental results in Fig. 2, it was found that the acid sites in the Ru-deAl-REUSY catalysts changed with the dealumination time, thereby affecting the yields of FA and LA. This may be because the content and type of acid sites of Ru-deAl-REUSY catalysts may affect the hydrolysis of reactants, hydrocarbon isomerization and reverse aldol condensation, etc., thus to affect the yields of FA and LA [51]. So, appropriate content and type acid sites played a crucial role in this catalytic reaction [52]. Therefore, the Ru-deAl-REUSY catalysts with 5 h dealumination time had a better catalytic effect on catalytic transfer hydrogenation reaction. 3.4.5 CO2-TPD characterization of catalysts The alkalinity of the catalyst in the CO2 catalytic conversion reaction may also be an important factor affecting the catalytic performance. Fig. 10 showed the CO2-TPD of different catalysts. The low temperature range is 200–350 °C, and the high temperature range is above 500 °C. It can be seen that the carrier REUSY mainly has strong alkaline sites, with almost no weak alkaline sites. By modifying the carrier REUSY, the weakly alkaline sites of the catalyst have increased, which is beneficial for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction in the low temperature range of our experimental conditions. Thus, it is inferred that only CO2 bound on weak alkaline sites can be easily further for participation in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. In addition, with the extension of dialuminium time, the weak alkaline sites and medium strong alkaline sites further disappeared. Combined with Fig. 2, it showed that the catalytic performance of the catalyst would be reduced if the dealumination time was too long. Compared to parent carrier of REUSY, the weak basic sites increased after the introduction of Ru, indicating that the Ru element promotes the hydrogenation reaction of CO2 by increasing the weak basic sites of the catalysts [53]. From this, the introduction of Ru into REUSY played a role in creating weak basic sites, and different dealumination time played a part in regulating the content of alkaline sites of different intensities [54]. 3.5 Catalyst stability research Reusability is one of the important indicators for evaluating the practical application of catalysts. From Fig. 11 a, it can be seen that during the second use of the Ru-deAl(5/10 h)-REUSY catalysts, there was a slight increase in the yields of LA and FA for both catalysts. However, during the third use, the yields of both catalysts decreased significantly. The XRD spectrum of the recovered 10 wt.% Ru-deAl (5 h) - REUSY catalyst was shown in Fig. 11b. It can be clearly seen that the catalyst reused for the second time still appeared RuO2 diffraction peaks at 28.0°, 35.0° and 54.2°, but the intensity decreased. It was observed that some impurity peaks belonging to the carrier disappeared at 10.0°∼28.0° which may be due to multiple distilled water washes during catalyst recovery, resulting in the loss of Ru and chloride ions and other useless components on the catalysts, thereby promoting the reaction [55,56]. When the catalyst continued to be recycled, the intensity of RuO2 diffraction peak decreased significantly, resulting in a significant decrease in catalytic activity. 4 Conclusions We herein developed a Ru-modified REUSY catalyst realizing catalytic transfer hydrogenation of CO2 with endogenous hydrogen induced by glycerol dehydrogenation. Experiments confirmed that under conditions of 200 °C, 36 h, and 7.92 g KHCO3, the reaction obtained the highest yields of FA and LA over 10 wt.% Ru-deAl(5 h)-REUSY, with 19.81 % and 6.13 % respectively. The extension of temperature and time can promote the process of CO2 catalytic hydrogenation reaction to some extent. The XPS results demonstrated that Ru4+ contribute to the glycerol dehydrogenation reaction and CO2 reduction conducted efficiently, but the valence state of Ru element was not a key factor affecting catalytic activity in this system. Py-IR and CO2-TPD characterization confirmed that the content and type of acid-base sites of Ru-deAl-REUSY catalysts may affect the hydrolysis of reactants, hydrocarbon isomerization and reverse aldol condensation, etc., thus to affect the yields of FA and LA. In addition, when replacing the carbon source from KHCO3 to CO2 (dry ice), FA and LA yields over 10 wt.% Ru-deAl(5 h)-REUSY catalysts were further improved, reaching 64.14 % and 17.13 %, respectively. In addition, Ru-deAl-REUSY catalysts have improved the yields of FA and LA in catalytic transfer hydrogenation reaction of CO2 with glycerol as hydrogen donor, which reduced the production cost of biodiesel and showed obvious advantages in atom economy, operating cost and process safety prospects. coredata.dc:description: In this work, a "hydrogen-free" strategy based on the ruthenium (Ru) modified REUSY molecular sieve catalysts was proposed, which can promote CO2 catalytic transfer hydrogenation using endogenous hydrogen induced by glycerol dehydrogenation. As the active component, Ru can not only act on the dehydrogenation reaction with glycerol, but also promote the hydrogenation reaction of CO2. Comparison experiments confirmed that under conditions of 200 °C, 36 h, and 7.92 g KHCO3, the reaction could obtain the highest yields over 10 wt.% Ru-deAl(5 h)-REUSY. The yields of formic acid and lactic acid were 19.81 % and 6.13 % respectively. In addition, when replacing the carbon source from KHCO3 to CO2 (dry ice), formic acid and lactic acid yields over 10 wt.% Ru-deAl(5 h)-REUSY catalysts were further improved, reaching 64.14 % and 17.13 %, respectively. This work demonstrated the feasibility of the "hydrogen-free" upgrade process realizing the catalytic transfer hydrogenation of CO2 into formic acid with glycerol as hydrogen donor.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic transfer hydrogenation of CO2 to formic acid with glycerol as the hydrogen donor over Ru-REUSY catalysts
